text: Home Articles Services My Requests More Search"" Profile Logout Managing My Assessments, Exams & Results 19 Aug 2025 Knowledge If you have experienced a short term, serious and unavoidable disruption that has impacted your ability to complete or prepare for an assessment task, you may be eligible to apply for Special Consideration.  Before you apply for Special Consideration, please read the following related articles, which will assist you with your application(s).  RelatedSpecial Consideration articles Eligibility -Am I eligible to apply for Special Consideration? Supporting evidence-What supporting evidence do I need to apply for Special Consideration? Attempt or submit -If I apply for Special Consideration do I still submit or attempt my assessment? IEAP planned extensions -How and when do use my IEAP planned extension via Special Consideration? Other FAQ -Frequently asked questions about Special Consideration?  How to apply: Check youreligibility, Gather yoursupporting documentation, Check the task(s) and unit(s) you need to apply for. As not every assessment task is assessable, please read theunit guidesand checkiLearnfor assessable tasks before applying, Complete aSpecial Consideration formand submit your application. Make sure you submit your application before, or no later than, five working days after the due date of the assessment task.  After submitting your Special Consideration application: While you wait for the outcome of your application please be mindful of the following: The University will aim to let you know of the outcome within 5 working days of applying. This may take longer during peak periods. Once fit to do so you should continue to work on your assessment and complete a finalised assessment as soon as possible. Outcomes will be reflective of the disruption period which is confirmed by supporting evidence. Therefore application outcomes such as retrospective extensions can occur (e.g. an extension date which has already past). Home Articles Services My Requests More Search"" Profile Logout Managing My Assessments, Exams & Results 19 Aug 2025 Knowledge Supporting evidence is a requirement of an application for Special Consideration. It determines if your application is eligible and impacts what the outcome to your application will be.  Supporting evidence must: identify the nature of the circumstances include dates and/or the length of the circumstances explain the severity and impact of the circumstances clearly describe how the circumstances have adversely affected your capacity for effective study related to the assessment/exam include the date(s) on which you were seen by the professional providing the evidence (if applicable)  Recommended supporting evidenceVarious documentation types can be used as supporting evidence, the below table outlines the recommended forms of evidence based on the disruption type. For a full list of acceptable evidence forms see theSpecial Consideration Supporting Evidence Schedule.  Official letter and/or documents from the relevant source/authority. For example: Wedding invitations accompanied by Statutory Declaration or Statement of Fact* Letter from religious leader/Elder Letter from employer stating why you cannot be released from the unexpected work commitments Letter from doctor/medical certificate Letter confirming your attendance to Jury Duty/court date  Here are answers to some frequently asked questions about supporting evidence:  A Statement of Fact can be used as supporting evidence: for all event/disruption types other than Elite Athlete commitments, if the event/disruption duration is 5 days or less, if it is used only once per assessment task (it cannot be used for the same assessment task more than once or to request a further outcome for the same assessment task). Multiple uses of a Statement of Fact in relation to the same disruption will be considered as a disruption that is longer than 5 days in duration, formal evidence will likely be requested instead.  If your Statement of Fact does not include sufficient detail, or if it does not allow for your circumstances to be confirmed as serious and unavoidable, it will not be accepted. Please provide independently corroborated forms of documentation that clearly demonstrate serious and unavoidable circumstances.  You do not have to include other evidence when applying, however you may be requested to provide additional supporting evidence when your application is reviewed. If you are able to obtain recommended supporting documentation forms, please use these documents rather than a Statement of Fact.  A RAT will not be accepted. Provide other medical evidence such as a medical certificate.  If your supporting evidence is not in English it cannot be assessed. This will result in your application being rejected for insufficient evidence.  It is a MQ form that students can have their health professional complete to then use as your supporting evidence. This includes all the relevant details your health professional needs to provide and can simply your application process. Students can access the MQ PAF via thefollowing link.  The university reviews all supporting evidence provided in Special Consideration applications.  Where misleading or fraudulent information/documents are submitted, this will be reported to the Complaints, Appeals and Misconduct Unit.  Any application with misleading or fraudulent information will be denied Special Consideration, and the likely outcome is 0% for the assessment task.  No further consideration for that assessment task will be given should other evidence be provided.  Related Special Consideration articles What is Special Consideration and how do I apply? Home Articles Services My Requests More Search"" Profile Logout Managing My Assessments, Exams & Results 19 Aug 2025 Knowledge If you have 'planned extension adjustments' for individual written assignments listed on yourIndividual Education Access Plan (IEAP), please refer to this article on IEAP for details about how to let us know that you would like to use the adjustment and for which assessment. For all other adjustment types refer to your IEAP for instructions.  Here are answers to some frequently asked questions about how and when to use your planned IEAP extension via Special Consideration:  If you are experiencing ongoing circumstances such as chronic illness, disability or carer commitments, you should explore support options such as reasonable adjustments offered through Accessibility Services at Student Wellbeing.  If you are registered with Accessibility Services, you may be eligible for reasonable adjustments for your studies, and this will simplify the circumstances in which you would need to apply for Special Consideration.  Special Consideration is applicable to short-term, serious, and unavoidable circumstances only.  Your IEAP planned extension can only be applied from the original assessment due date. If you have already received an approved Special Consideration extension and still require extra time, you cannot then submit a Planned Extension application.   Supporting evidence requirements vary based on your reason for applying. If you have an adjustment for planned extension listed on your IEAP and you wish to use that extension, you will need to request this on yourSpecial Consideration formunder the event category of 'Planned extension with IEAP adjustment'. You do not need to attach any evidence to your application.  If you are unable to complete an assessment task due to other impacts separate to that of your IEAP or experience an additional disruption, you will need to provide valid forms ofsupporting evidence.  Your IEAP can only be used to request one extension per assessment task. After this, you will need to provide other valid forms of supporting evidence.  Important:An IEAP planned extension provision can be applied towards eligible assessment types only. Please refer to your IEAP for details as to which assessments are covered by your IEAP.  Planned extension adjustments cannot be used for missing quiz/tests/exams or to request extra time to complete a quiz/test/exam.  If you are unable to sit a quiz/test/exam at the scheduled date/time, you will need to apply for special consideration, providing evidence relating to the disruption that has prevented you from sitting the quiz/test/exam.  Extra time for tests, quizzes, or exams will be applied as per the listed adjustments on your students IEAP (eg. 25% extra time) – you do not need to submit a special consideration request to have your extra time adjustments applied.  You can apply for your IEAP extension forlong-form individual written assessments only.  The following assessments tasks arenot coveredunder this recommended adjustment: short written tasks in-class/online tests exams/supplementary exams presentations group work activities weekly tasks PACE/placement take home assignments and exams class attendance clinical and practical assessment tasks timed assessments  We will review your IEAP extension request and will aim to respond within five working days.  You should continue to work on your assessment task while you wait for the notification of the outcome of your request. If you do not hear a response prior to the due date, you should work towards submitting the assessment task on the due date aligned with your IEAP. Other common questions you might have regarding the Special Consideration process and applications can be found below:  Final Exams and Supplementary Exams  Criteria relating to Session 2 2025 Final Exams has not yet been released. Further information is expected to be made available once the Draft Examination Timetable is released on approx. the 1/10/2025. In the meantime, please ensure you carefully check your unit mode and assessment requirements when enrolling.  If your LAWS unit Take Home Exam clashes with a formal Final Exam as listed on the Examination Timetable, you may apply for Special Consideration for the LAWS unit only. A clash is eligible for Spec Con if both assessments occur at the same time or within one hour of another. Students should wait until the Final Exam Timetable is released before applying.  If approved for Special Consideration in relation to a final exam (which occurred during the formal examination period) you may be granted a supplementary exam. If granted a Supplementary Exam, the Supplementary Exam period occurs: For Session 2 2025 units:  11/12/2025-23/12/2025 For Session 3 2025 units: 16/02/2026-19/02/2026 For Session 1 2026 units:  9/07/2026-21/07/2026 If approved for a Supplementary Exam students are expected to ensure their availability during this period.   Application Process & Form  You should apply no later than five (5) working days after the assessment date. If you are applying more than five (5) working days after the assessment date, you must justify or explain this timing in your application. Applications submitted outside the required timeframe are not guaranteed and are only considered for Special Consideration in exceptional circumstances.  You may add more than one unit and/or assessment to your application form. To add more units/assessment to your form use the 'Add' button.  If your unit doesn’t appear as an option in your Special Consideration form it is because you are no longer enrolled in the unit. If you have received a result (eg P, F, FA), and you believe it’s incorrect due to a previously approved Special Consideration, you may need to submit a Grade Appeal instead. Once final results are released, you can’t use Special Consideration to explain something that’s already affected your grade.​ Reminder: Special Consideration needs to be submitted within 5 working days of the assessment due date.   After Applying  Please check your outcome email which will explain: why your application was not approved, and/or may have advice or instructions for further actions if appropriate. Please note in some instances your Special Consideration might have been closed requesting you instead reapply with missing evidence/information/application details in order then reassess your application. If you wish submit an academic appeal, refer to the appeals web page for more information. Appeals must be submitted within 10 working days of your application outcome. We recommend you consult the Special Consideration articles and policy prior to submitting an appeal. Applications must be submitted no later than five working days after the assessment due date. If an application is beyond this deadline and therefore is submitted after the release of final results, it is too late to be considered. Home Articles Services My Requests More Search"" Profile Logout Managing & Understanding My Course Graduation 2 Oct 2024 Knowledge  Complete the Course Guidance Self Check. If you require further assistance after completing this self check, you can submit a question via theCourse Guidance form.  You can submit aQualification Check formby theCensus Dateof your final study period.  If you are a coursework student, youcan submit aQualification Check formto exit with a single degree from a double degree. Please review the details of your course and provide details of any changes required. Important:Please specify what degree or qualification you want to exit from.  If you are in your final study period and currently admitted in the Bachelor of Psychology (Hons) course, however, would like to graduate without Honours, please state this on theQualification Check form.  If there are missing major/minors and/or specialisations on yourQualification Check form, please edit as required.  If you are studying a Higher Course Research program, please refer to theGraduate Research Academyfor further information.  If you do not meet the requirements for your course at the end of the nominated completion period, you will not be qualified, and your course status will remain as 'admitted'. Please refer to the Qualification Self-Check in theCourse Guidance Formto confirm you meet all the requirements for your course. If you have incomplete grades at the time of completion, you will not be qualified at result release. We will assess you for qualification within 15 business days of your incomplete grades being finalised.  Exiting your course means that you are graduating with an approved lower award provided you meet the requirements. Home Articles Services My Requests More Search"" Profile Logout Managing & Understanding My Course Course Changes 28 Aug 2025 Knowledge If you are starting your first session at Macquarie and are not sure what units you need to take, there are several different resources you can use. Please checkUnit levelsandUnit Offeringsto understand what these mean when choosing your units. TheCourseHandbookis where you can find your course structure. You can use the Handbook to view different course components (including majors, minors, specialisation), unit offerings, learning outcomes and pre-requisites. The Handbook is a great tool to help you plan the units you need to undertake. For a guide on what units to study when you first start your course, theEnrolment Guidescan help recommend a list of units to enrol into. These guides are created by the faculty, but please note these guides are still only a suggestion and you are free to enrol into other units if you wish. If you are more than half-way through your course, you can complete a self-check via theCourse Guidance Tool. Home Articles Services My Requests More Search"" Profile Logout Managing & Understanding My Course Course Progression 5 Aug 2025 Knowledge You can apply for Withdrawal Without Penalty (WWP) if you have: been impacted by a serious and unavoidable disruption after the census date experienced circumstances that have prevented you from successfully passing or completing a unit. Please note:You cannot apply for Withdrawal Without Penalty for units that you have passed. Withdrawal Without Penalty will be granted where Macquarie University is satisfied that the circumstances you faced: were beyond your control did not make their full impact until on, or after the census date for the unit of study, and made it impracticable to complete the requirements for the unit during the period for which the student undertook or was to undertake the unit Before you begin: Familiarise yourself withWithdrawal Without Penalty policy Prepare your supporting documentation to attach with your application. Then complete and submit theWithdrawal Without Penalty form. If you feel in need of any additional support, Macquarie University offers severalPersonal Support Servicesthat you can reach at any time. Home Articles Services My Requests More Search"" Profile Logout Managing & Understanding My Course 14 July 2025 Knowledge With concurrent studies you can complete an approved unit at another Australian institution and have it credited towards your admitted course at Macquarie University.  You will find answers to frequently asked questions about concurrent studies below.  To be eligible for concurrent studies: You must be a Commonwealth Supported student You must not have an Academic Standing of Academic Pause You must apply for a unit at an Australian Institution  Units taken at another university do not count towards a full-time status and they donotcontribute towards your Weighted Average Mark (WAM) at Macquarie University.  You are responsible for contacting the other institution to confirm application dates, procedures and appropriate documentation. Important:Macquarie University does not contact other institutions on your behalf.  To be eligible for concurrent studies, you must be a Commonwealth Supported Place (CSP) student. You can find out more atCommonwealth Supported Places.  You will need to apply via theRecognition of Prior Learning (RPL)form and attach the following documentation to support your request: Relevant unit guide/s from the external institution; and A completed cross-institutional studies form from the external institution  When completing theRecognition of Prior Learning (RPL)application,follow the instructions below to differentiate your concurrent studies application from an RPL application: In the Requested specific credit screen:List the institution you plan on taking the concurrent studies (i.e. Griffith University)Course is “Concurrent Studies”Course Type is “Other”Course Duration is “6 months” List the institution you plan on taking the concurrent studies (i.e. Griffith University) Course is “Concurrent Studies” Course Type is “Other” Course Duration is “6 months” Continue to complete the rest of the RPL form  Applications for concurrent studies generally take up to 20 business days to be completed.Once approved, you will receive an official letter that shows your approved concurrent studies application.  Once you have completed the approved concurrent study unit(s) and your transcript is available. Please submit a newRecognition of Prior Learning (RPL)request via the Service Connect Portal. In this application, please attach your official transcript along with the approval letter we have provided you. This will fast track the PRL process, and the approved credit will be applied to your course without the need for any further approval. Please note, the transcript must clearly show that you have successfully passed the unit(s) for the credit to be applied to your current course  Reduce Study Load - How to apply INTL UG PG MQ CollegeNumber of Views3.68K Suspension of studies - How to - INTL UG PG MQ CollegeNumber of Views776 Reduce Study Load - FAQ INTL UG PG MQ CollegeNumber of Views3.41K Confirmation of Enrolment - how to apply for extensionNumber of Views1.31K Late Unit Enrolment - How to applyNumber of Views618 Am I eligible for Special Consideration? Meet the course entry requirements listed in theCourse Transfer Requirements Table.NOTE: All course transfers are not automatic, and not all courses are available for transfer. If not, your application will be cancelled. Not all requirements allow for RPL to be used towards entry. If not, your application will be cancelled. Not all requirements allow for RPL to be used towards entry. Weighted Average Mark (WAM): Some Course Transfer requirements ask that you successfully complete a certain overall WAM before transferring. Home Articles Services My Requests More Search"" Profile Logout Managing & Understanding My Course Course Progression 27 May 2025 Knowledge Suspension of Studies (SoS)allows international students who are experiencing compassionate or compelling circumstances to take a break from study.  Here are answers to some frequently asked questions about Suspension of Studies.  If you are an international student and you are unable to study for the current or upcoming session due to compassionate or compelling circumstances, you must apply for a Suspension of Studies.  These are circumstances beyond your control that may affect your ability to attend classes and study. Examples include: Serious medical illness or injury to you or a close family member Death of a family member, such as a parent or grandparent A major political upheaval or natural disaster in your home country requiring emergency travel or disrupting your studies A traumatic experience, such as an accident There are no available units for you to enrol for the current study period  The eligibility requirements to apply for Suspension of studies are: You must be admitted to a Macquarie University degree You must be admitted to a Macquarie University degree You haverecordedgrades (i.e., you are not in your first session or term) You haverecordedgrades (i.e., you are not in your first session or term) You are not on Academic Pause You are not on Academic Pause You do not have outstanding debts; you must pay them before you apply for SoS You do not have outstanding debts; you must pay them before you apply for SoS  Applications may take up to20 business daysto process from the day you submit your application.   Please note that you must apply before the census date of the study period that you are applying for to avoid anyfinancial penalties.   Some circumstances will not be considered compassionate and compelling. For example: Students have financial difficulty Students have financial difficulty Students want to change majors or course in the future study period Students want to change majors or course in the future study period Students failed to enrol in course by thelast date to enrolor the Late Unit Enrolment was not approved Students failed to enrol in course by thelast date to enrolor the Late Unit Enrolment was not approved Students have work commitments Students have work commitments   Related articles Suspension of Studies Financial Sanctions  Recognition of Prior Learning - EligibilityNumber of Views1.5K Recognition of Prior Learning - How to applyNumber of Views3.43K Academic StandingNumber of Views761 Recognition of Prior Learning - FAQNumber of Views3.54K Concurrent Studies FAQ DOM UG PG MQ CollegeNumber of Views1.51K Am I eligible for Special Consideration? Home Articles Services My Requests More Search"" Profile Logout Managing & Understanding My Enrolment Making Changes To My Study Load 19 Aug 2025 Knowledge  For international students, if you wish to withdraw from a unit: Log intoeStudent, navigate to 'My Study' tile and select 'Manage my course' Click on 'Withdraw from a unit' on the left-hand side Select the units you wish to withdraw from, and click 'Confirm' On the next page, select 'Ok' if you wish to proceed with withdrawing from the unit(s) Withdraw before the official Census Date for each session to avoid an academic and financial penalty.  If you withdraw from a unitafterthe census date but on or before the Last Withdrawal Date, you will be regarded as 'Withdrawn' (W). No academic penalty is associated with a withdrawn status and this will not be included in the calculation of your Weighted Average Mark (WAM). However, you will remain financially liable for the unit.  Before you begin: Ensure you familiarise yourself with theAcademic Datesto be aware of the consequences of withdrawing at different times within the study period.  Important info: As a student visa holder, you must follow your visa conditions to ensure you satisfy its requirements. You are required to be a full-time student and enrol in compulsory study periods to complete your studies within the stated timeframe on your Confirmation of Enrolment (CoE).  If you are experiencing academic difficulties or situations which are considered to be compassionate or compelling, you could be eligible to apply for Reduce Study Load.  For further information relating to your student visa conditions, please visitthis webpageand the related articles in the Service Connect Portal.  Quick tip: If you need more help understanding how to withdraw from a unit, please view ourWithdrawing from Units eStudent tutorial video. Home Articles Services My Requests More Search"" Profile Logout Managing & Understanding My Enrolment 4 July 2025 Knowledge At The College, enrolment for each Term closes at 9pm on the Sunday before each Term begins. However, during the first week of Term, students can request Late Enrolment. If approved, you will be manually enrolled into your requested units and registered for classes. The number of  units you can be Late Enrolled in depends on how soon you apply: If you apply before 12pm (midday) on Wednesday of Week 1,andyour application can be approved, you can be Late Enrolled intoTwo Units. If you apply after 12pm on Wednesday, but before 12pm on Friday of Week 1,andyour application can be approved, you can be Late Enrolled intoOne Unit. Any applications submitted after 12pm on Friday of Week 1 will not be approved. Submit theLate Unit Enrolment Formvia theService Connect Portal. If you need assistance, just come to The Student Hub to see an Advisor without needing an appointment any time between 9am and 4pm during the first week of Term (Ground Floor, 8 Sir Christopher Ondaatje Avenue).  Quick Tip:To make sure that your application has the best chance of being approved be sure to: Update your personal address and contact details. Clear any sanctions you may have on your account - if you have any sanctions, your request will not be approved. When you apply, make sure you check the Handbook to ensure the units you are applying for are available in the current Term. Be sure you write the correct Unit Code in your application, and make sure all the information is accurate. Also, make sure you already meet the Prerequisites for enrolment in your selected unit. If you don't meet the prerequisites, you won't be approved!  But What If I'm Not Approved? If you aren't approved for late enrolment, we recommend contacting a College Student Advisor at The Student Hub ASAP so they can help plan your remaining units. If this is during Week 1 of a Term, just come to The Student Hub to see an Advisor without needing an appointment. You can also submit an enquiry using theService Connect Portal. Additionally, if you are an International Student, a rejected Late Enrolment will mean either you will be studying 1 unit (part-time) or have no units at all. If this is the case, you will now need to either apply for a Reduced Study Load (for 1 unit) or a Suspension of Studies (for no units) as soon as possible to prevent the cancellation of your eCoE and the discontinuation of your course. These applications must be submitted by the Census day (Friday of Week 3). It is highly recommended you met with a Student Advisor before submitting either application. Home Articles Services My Requests More Search"" Profile Logout Managing & Understanding My Enrolment Class Registration & Timetables 15 May 2025 Knowledge Ifyou’retrying to enrol in a unit butdon’tmeet the listed requisites(i.e.prerequisitesorcorequisites), you may be able to request Special Approval (also known as a waiver).This process allows the University to consider your academic background, experience,or otherrelevant qualificationsto see ifyou’reready to succeed in the unit. Youcan findtheRequisites foreach unitintheCourse Handbook. You may need to apply for Special Approval in the following scenarios: Youdon’tmeet a unit’s requisites butthink you are eligible to study You believe you meet theunit's requisites buteStudentdoes not recognise this Youcan’tenrol in a unitrequiredfor your course because you have studiedan anti-requisite/NCCW unit The unitrequires‘Permission by Special Approval’. Why do I need to apply for Special Approval? ForeStudenttodetermineif you meet the requisites for a unit, you must first‘schedule’ a unit via ‘Plan & Enrol’ pagefor a specific study period. Ifyou see the message‘Unsatisfied requisite’when trying to enrol in a unit, it means youhaven’tmet the requirements(calledrequisites) to enrol in that unit. Here’swhat to donext: If the unit is a core (required) unit in your course:To enrol in a core unit with ‘Unsatisfied requisites’,you need to complete therequisites listed on the Course Handbook.If you candemonstratethat you meet the requisites,you’llneed to apply forspecialapproval to enrol in the unit. If the unit is not a core unit:It’s best to choose another unitwhereyou meet the requisites. Ifthere’sno suitableoption, you can apply forspecialapproval and explain your situation. Home Articles Services My Requests More Search"" Profile Logout Managing & Understanding My Enrolment 15 May 2025 Knowledge Requisiteis a requirement or condition you must meet to enrol in a unit. There aredifferent typesof requisites. Prerequisite-a requirement or condition you must meet before you can enrol in a unit. This could be the completion of another unit or meeting a specific conditionsuch as completion of certain credit points (cp) or specific units. Corequisite-a unit you must complete at the same time or before anotherunit. Anti-requisite/Not to Count for Credit With (NCCW) -units are considered too similar in content or learning outcomes to both count towards the same course. Permission by Special Approval- some units such as research projects, PACE units or special interest topics require permission to enrol even if there are no listed requisites.These also go through the Special Approval (waiver) process. You can find the Requisites for each unit in theCourse Handbook. Home Articles Services My Requests More Search"" Profile Logout Managing My Assessments, Exams & Results Academic Appeals 28 Aug 2025 Knowledge Macquarie University is committed to a transparent, equitable and consistent approach on decisions that affect students.  Academic Appealsare when you request that the University review the process by which a decision was made. Appeals do not review the merits of that decision; instead, the focus is on the decision-making process. For example, you can appeal because you believe a Grade Appeal was not conducted fairly, but you cannot appeal the outcome of a Grade Appeal because you disagree with the outcome of the Grade Appeal. Your appeal must clearly identify how the procedure for dealing with your issue was unfair, and detail that one or more the following grounds for appeal occurred: the required procedure for making the decision was not followed there was a lack of procedural fairness in making the decision new information has become available that was not available at the time the decision was made and which should be taken into consideration. You must provide reasoning and supporting information to show that the decision made by the University was unfair due to one of the grounds listed above. You must also demonstrate that as a result of one of these grounds existing or occurring, the decision was substantially unfair. Your appeal will be unsuccessful if you are unable to demonstrate that one of the grounds existed or occurred and that the decision was substantially unjust.  You may appeal any of the following types of decisions and the relevant timeframes are: 10 working days Admission or re-admission to a degree Recognition of Prior Learning (RPL) Academic integrity breaches (breaches or penalty decisions, except Suspension or Exclusion) Special Consideration Enrolment and Leave of Absence Withdrawal (including Withdrawal Without Penalty) Outcome of a Grade Appeal 20 working days Academic Pause or Exclusion under the Academic Progression policy Academic integrity breaches (Suspension or Exclusion penalties) Exclusion under the General Coursework Rules Suspension of Studies Notice of Intent to Report Fitness to practice requirement under the Fitness to Practice Procedure Termination of candidature (Higher Degree Research) Award of PhD, MPhil or MRes degree Research degree enrolment, leave of absence and withdrawal decisions under the Higher Degree Research Variations to Candidature Policy Please note that late appeals can only be accepted if you can show circumstances beyond your control which prevented you from submitting your appeal on time.  Once you have lodged yourAcademic Appeal application, you will receive an automatic confirmation that your application has been received. We begin processing your appeal within 10 working days and we aim to process your appeal as quickly and informally as possible. However, some appeals are more complex and may take more than 30 Working days to finalise. You will be kept informed of your application progress via your student email account. We may also request additional information from you at any stage of this process. In cases of Academic Pause or Exclusion, you may be invited to meet with an Academic Appeals Panel.  The outcome of your Academic Appeal application will be sent to your student email address. If your appeal is successful (or 'upheld'), there may be several possible outcomes: The original decision may be overturned, and your original request sent for action to the appropriate team/sThe original decision may be sent to a new decision-maker in the relevant area for reconsideration, following appropriate processes. This means that a new decision will be made, through it is important to note this does not mean that a different result will be reached; for example, a successful appeal may not necessarily result in your candidature being reinstated. The original decision may be overturned, and your original request sent for action to the appropriate team/s The original decision may be sent to a new decision-maker in the relevant area for reconsideration, following appropriate processes. This means that a new decision will be made, through it is important to note this does not mean that a different result will be reached; for example, a successful appeal may not necessarily result in your candidature being reinstated. If your Academic Appeal is unsuccessful (or 'dismissed'), you may also have further options outside of the University. Agencies that you may consider include: NSW OmbudsmanAustralian Human Rights CommissionAnti-Discrimination Board of NSWAudit Office of NSWNSW Independent Commission Against CorruptionInformation and Privacy Commission NSW NSW Ombudsman Australian Human Rights Commission Anti-Discrimination Board of NSW Audit Office of NSW NSW Independent Commission Against Corruption Information and Privacy Commission NSW  Further information If you are uncertain of the procedures or need help to submit your appeal, you can contact the Complaints, Appeals and Misconduct team onAcademic_Appeals@mq.edu.au. Or contactStudent Advocacyfor advice. Home Articles Services My Requests More Search"" Profile Logout Managing My Assessments, Exams & Results Academic Appeals 21 Jan 2025 Knowledge If you are considering appealing your grade, you must submit aGrade Appeal formwithin 15 business days of official notification of your final grade.  Read theAssessment PolicyandAssessment Procedure. Read the information on theAppealing a University decisionwebpage.  Before you lodge an application for Grade Appeal, you should make a booking to review your exam script. This is important for claims of administrative errors during final exams.  Macquarie Business School Please register for an exam script view using theMQBS registration form. Please advise us of the specific unit you are seeking to view the exam script(s) for. Macquarie Business School will send you an email reminder prior to your registered script viewing date. Please see the scheduled script viewing dates in this form Faculty of Arts, Faculty of Medicine Health and Human Sciences and Faculty of Science and Engineering Please contact your unit convenor to organise a script viewing. Please note: You cannot view exam scripts for units with 'I' or 'IS' results as these units have not yet been finalised. If you have been awarded a supplementary exam, only the supplementary exam can be viewed, and the original exam is null and void. You may need to keep copies of your emails as evidence in your appeal. Macquarie College Please send an enquiry viaService Connect Portalwith the subject 'Final Exam Script Viewing' and include the Unit Code in your request.  You can contactStudent Advocacyfor assistance with your grade appeal. Student Advocacy provides free, confidential and independent information and advice about University policies and procedures.  Please contactStudent Wellbeingif you need personal support. Home Articles Services My Requests More Search"" Profile Logout Managing My Details, Documents & Cards 22 July 2025 Knowledge Your academic transcript is a document which includes units, results, credit points, course completion and/or conferral of award details. If you are studying with us, you can access yourunofficialtranscript viaeStudent. If you require anofficialtranscript, please note the following information. Important:If you were a student before 2008, please refer to theTranscript request: Before 2008. Further information can be found onAcademic transcripts.  Transcripts take up to 3 business days to be processed. Once you have made your payment, the processing times apply as follows: Collection from Friday, for example: order 2.00 pm Tuesday – available Friday order 4.00 pm Wednesday – available Friday order 10.00 am Thursday – available Friday Collection from Wednesday, for example: order 12.00 pm Friday – available Wednesday order 3.00 pm Monday – available Wednesday order 9.00 am Tuesday – available Wednesday  If you studied at the Sydney Kindergarten Teachers College (SKTC), Nursery School Teachers College (NSTC) or Institute of Early Childhood Studies (IECS) prior to 1990, your transcript request may also take more time to process as this is historical information requiring collation.  To have a nominated third party collect document(s) on your behalf you will need to select this option in the online gateway at the time you purchase your transcript. Make sure to advise your third party they will need to provide an official form of photo identification at the time of collection (e.g. driver licence or passport). Home Articles Services My Requests More Search"" Profile Logout Managing My Details, Documents & Cards International Student Requirements 10 July 2025 Knowledge If you are an international student visa holder, you must: maintain full study load, and complete your course within the time specified on yourConfirmation of Enrolment (COE) However, you may be eligible to reduce your study load if you experience academic difficulties, or circumstances which are compassionate and compelling in nature. We encourage you to seek support from various studentsupport servicesavailable at Macquarie University.  You are not required to apply for a reduced study load if: You are in your final study period and have fewer than 40 credit points remaining to complete your course, or You were provided with a Study Plan at the time of admission that already includes a reduced load in specific study periods.  What is a full study load for an international student visa holder? A full-time load for international students is: For Macquarie University session-based students: 40 credit points (4 units) in each compulsory study period (Session 1 and Session 2) For Macquarie University term-based students: 20 credit points (2 units) each term.  What are the circumstances to apply for reduce study load? There are circumstances beyond your control that may affect your ability study full load, and you must provide evidence to support your application: Academic reason  Received guidance: You have received advice from the faculty to reduce study load. Implementation of academic intervention strategies: Your academic standing is monitored enrolment, and you are required to reduce study load to assist with your academic performance.  Compelling reason  Required unit unavailable in specific study period: You have no other units available to enrol in to maintain a full study load including flexible zone and electives. Delay in the outcome Appeal/Advice: For example, if your grades are not finalised in time, it may impact your ability to enrol in a full load.  Compassionate reason  Serious Illness: A health problem that is serious and impact your ability to study full load.  Traumatic Experiences: These are very stressful or shocking events that cause emotional pain, such as accidents, natural disasters, or experiencing violence and impact your ability to study full load.  Bereavement of Close Family Members: This means the sadness and mourning someone feels when a close family member and impact your ability to study full load.  Political Unrest in Home Countries: This refers to a situation where there is conflict, violence, or instability in your home country and impact your ability to study full load.  What are the ineligible circumstances for reduced study load? Some of the ineligible circumstances for reducing your study load include: Student having financial difficulty. Students want to change majors or course in the future study period. Student failed to enrol in your course by thelast date to enrolor the Late Unit Enrolment was not approved. Student have work commitments. Recognition Prior Learning Application was not approved  When should I apply for a reduced study load? You must apply for aReduce Study Loadbefore thecensus dateof the study period to avoid anypenalties. No Reduced Study Load applications will be accepted after theLast Withdrawal Without Fail date. You may consider submitting aWithdrawal Without Penaltyform if you meet the eligibility criteria.  How long will my application take? Applications to reduce your study load generally take 20 business days to be processed.  What happens if my application to reduce my study load is not approved? If your application for a reduced study load is not approved, you must continue to study a full load in order to complete your course as per your Confirmation of Enrolment (CoE). If a student decides to reduce their study load without approval, their request for a COE extension may not be approved, potentially preventing them from completing their course.  ***ImportantYou must remain enrolled infull-time study loaduntil your application has been finalised.  ***  Related articles How to apply for Reduce Study Load Suspension of studies Full-time study load for international students Confirmation of Enrolment Reduce Study Load - How to apply INTL UG PG MQ CollegeNumber of Views3.68K Suspension of studies - How to - INTL UG PG MQ CollegeNumber of Views777 Confirmation of Enrolment - how to apply for extensionNumber of Views1.31K Concurrent Studies FAQ DOM UG PG MQ CollegeNumber of Views1.51K Late Unit Enrolment - How to applyNumber of Views618 Am I eligible for Special Consideration? Home Articles Services My Requests More Search"" Profile Logout Managing My Details, Documents & Cards International Student Requirements 10 July 2025 Knowledge You can apply for an extension of your CoE if you’re applying for a student visa extension and meet at least one of the following criteria: you have an approved Reduced Study Load (RSL) or Suspension of Studies (SoS) from previous study period you have failed units or been placed on Monitored Enrolment that prevent you from completing your studies within the duration of your current CoE you are experiencing compassionate or compelling circumstances, and you can provide evidence to support this assessment. Your CoE application will not be processed if: you have a valid CoE with more than 3 months remaining until your visa expires your results for the current study period have not been released your contact details (current Australian address and mobile number) are not up to date in eStudent you did not maintain a full-time study load during a compulsory study period, and you did not have prior approval from Macquarie University (an approved Suspension of Studies or Reduced Study Load.) you do not have compassionate or compelling circumstances, or you are unable to provide supporting evidence you have outstanding debts. Home Articles Services My Requests More Search"" Profile Logout Managing My Details, Documents & Cards 27 Mar 2025 Knowledge If you are a New Zealand citizen on a Special Category Visa (SCV) or have previously held a SCV, you may be eligible to borrow the cost of your tuition fees from the Commonwealth Government. If you meet the eligibility requirements and you borrow your fees, you will be required to repay theamount you borrow via theAustralian Tax Office (ATO). To be eligible, you must meet the long-term residency requirements and be living in Australia for the duration of your course of study. You can find answers to frequently asked questions about New Zealand SCV holder below.  If you are unsure if you are aNew Zealand Special Category Visa holder, you will be able to check this on theVisa Entitlement Verification Online (VEVO)system, from theDepartment of Home Affairs(DHA).  If you believe you meet all the SCV criteria, and you would like to request HELP assistance, you will need to complete all steps below before the nextcensus date: Complete theResidency Verificationform Provide evidence that you currently hold a NZ Special Category Visa (SCV) i.e. a copy of your NZ passport Show evidence that you have been ordinarily resident in Australia for at least 10 years, and that you were under the age of 18 without a spouse or de facto partner when you first began to be ordinarily resident in Australia, and Show evidence that you have been in Australia for at least: a total of eight out of the past 10 years; anda total of 18 months out of the last two years a total of eight out of the past 10 years; and a total of 18 months out of the last two years  You will need to show that you have been ordinarily resident in Australia by showing continuity of residency. Examples of proof include: AnInternational Movement Records(the most comprehensive form of evidence available from the Department of Home Affairs, allow 28 days for processing) Australian academic transcripts (including VET transcripts) dated when you were a minor School reports or certificates Enrolment papers from when you were a minorAustralian proof of age card from when you were a minorAustralian student ID card or concession cardStamped passportPay slips or payment summaries from when you were a minorCertificate of application for a Tax File Number (TFN), TFN advice or notification of assessment of income tax dated from when you were a minor Australian proof of age card from when you were a minor Australian student ID card or concession card Stamped passport Pay slips or payment summaries from when you were a minor Certificate of application for a Tax File Number (TFN), TFN advice or notification of assessment of income tax dated from when you were a minor Important:You must provide all required documents and be assessed as eligible by the next relevantcensus dateto be able to defer your fees for the session. Otherwise, you must make full payment of fees upfront for that session. Further information about upfront payment can be found onHow to Pay.  Along with the above evidence, the most accurate form of evidence is anInternational Movements Recordavailable at no cost from theDepartment of HomeAffairs(DHA). Please be aware that it may take up to 28 days for your application to be completed. You can also submit a previous copy of aVEVOrecord and you must also establish that you meet the residency requirements.  You will receive an email with the outcome of your NZ SCV application within 15 business days from the date of submission.  Yes, you must submit a new request for HECS-HELP / FEE-HELP via aneCAFform ineStudent.  Further information can be found on the Australian government’sStudyAssistwebsite. Home Articles Services My Requests More Search"" Profile Logout Managing My Details, Documents & Cards 29 Jan 2025 Knowledge To change or verify your residency, you must inform us by submitting theResidency Verification formwith appropriate documentation prior to the next census date of your study period. This article has answers to questions about Residency Verification for Permanent Residents (Non-humanitarian) or New Zealand Citizens.  If you have become a Permanent Resident (Non-humanitarian) or New Zealand citizen, you must submit one of the following via theResidency Verification form: a copy of the photo page of your passport or a copy of your ImmiCard University staff will verify your residency status onVEVOand if approved, you will be advised to submit a new eCAF  No, as a Permanent Resident (Non-humanitarian) or a non-eligible New Zealand citizen, you cannot borrow the cost of your tuition fees from the Australian Government.  If you have paid international tuition fees upfront and your residency status has been successfully changed to Permanent Resident or New Zealand citizenbeforethe nextcensus date, you will be eligible for a refund if there is a difference between the international and new domestic rates. As such, you can either request a refund of any credit amount. Please seeRefund Request for Domestic StudentsorRefund Request for International Studentsfor information on refunds.  Important:if there is any outstanding amount, you are required to pay the difference. Home Articles Services My Requests More Search"" Profile Logout Managing My Fees & Costs Fee Sanctions 2 June 2025 Knowledge What is a financial sanction and what does it do? A financial sanction is a restriction applied to a student's account that may impact their ability to accessexam results request academic transcriptsor other official documents enrol in new units graduate There are six financial sanction codes, namelyDWO, INF, SSA, LPF, LFD, and FIN. Financial sanctions may be applied to a student's account when they fail to pay their outstanding fees and other charges as shown in their eStudent account.  What should I do if there is a financial sanction on my account? If your sanction is either DWO or FIN, please reach out to the Student Debt Management team at 02 9850 7230 to determine how these sanctions can be lifted. If your sanction is one of INF, SSA, LFD and LPF,  you must pay any outstanding fees as shown on your eStudent account. You can pay your fees througheStudentvia theMy Finances.For information about payment methods, please refer to theHow to Pay page. Please be advised that it may take upto three business days for sanctions to be lifted from your account. Home Articles Services My Requests More Search"" Profile Logout Managing My Fees & Costs 9 May 2025 Knowledge What is a Statement of Outstanding Charges/Tax Invoice?A statement of outstanding charges/tax Invoice is an official university document showing your current outstanding fees.  Why do I need a Statement of Outstanding Charges/Tax Invoice? The statement of outstanding charges/tax Invoice provides a list of outstanding fees in your account.This official document can be provided to third parties—such as banks, employers, and sponsors—to confirm the fee amounts you are required to pay to Macquarie University.  How can I get my Statement of Outstanding Charges/Tax Invoice? Log in toeStudentwith your OneID account. SelectMy Study, then clickManage My Courses. Go toSelf-Service Report. Click onRequestbutton againstStatement of Outstanding Charges/Tax Invoice. The system will send theStatement of Outstanding Charges/Tax Invoiceto your official university student email address. Home Articles Services My Requests More Search"" Profile Logout Managing My Fees & Costs 26 Dec 2024 Knowledge Macquarie has one of the most generous international scholarship programs in Australia. This includes a wide variety of long and short term opportunities for international students. The range of scholarships available can depend on the country you are from, with other eligibility factors including your field of study and academic or sporting achievements.  You can find answers to frequently asked questions about scholarships below. What scholarships are available to me?I have questions about the scholarship application process  There are limited number of scholarships, so we encourage you to accept your offer early to avoid disappointment. Some scholarships have acceptance deadlines which you must meet to be eligible for the scholarship. If you miss out on the deadline or require further information, contact Future Students team atstudy@mq.edu.au.  Most scholarship offers cannot be deferred; however, you may be able to reapply in the subsequent round. Check the details of the individual scholarship to see your options.  Scholarship payments are processed after the scholarships are reviewed at the end of each study period. Direct scholarship payments will be made into your bank account by the end of April and September. Fee reduction scholarships are progressively credited to your tuition fees once you have enrolled in your units for the relevant study period(s). You can check that your scholarship has been applied, in eStudent under 'View student finances', click on 'Click Here for Details' next to 'My Sponsorships/Scholarships' section.  International student scholarships are generally fee reductions where payment is processed close to the start of each study period. Two weeks before your payment due date, you can check that your scholarship has been applied. To do this, go to eStudent under 'View student finances', click on 'Click Here for Details' next to 'My Sponsorships/Scholarships' section.  If your scholarship payment is via direct payment into your bank account, you will need to enter your banking details in eStudent, through the following steps: Select 'View Student Finances' From the left menu, select 'Preferences' In Payment Methods, select 'Electronic Funds Transfer In Bank Transfer Method, select BSB, the code must be 6 digits only Quick tip:Use the following format and do not include any other characters or blank space between numbers. Home Articles Services My Requests More Search"" Profile Logout Managing My Assessments, Exams & Results Exam Support 25 Sept 2024 Knowledge Clash means two Final Examinations overlapping for any period of time, or with less than one-hour break between two Final Examinations on the same day. Students will be notified by the Examinations Office of arrangements that will be made if their exams clash. If the clash occurs between a Final Examination and a take-home examination, the Final Exam will take precedence. Apply forSpecial Considerationfor your take-home examination. I have two exams on the same day - Can I move one of these exams? No. If you have two exams scheduled on the same day at different start times (for example, at 9.00am and 1.30pm), you cannot move these exams and you are expected to sit both.  Quick tip:If you experience serious and unavoidable difficulties at exam time or when assessment tasks are due, you can consider applying forSpecial Consideration. Home Articles Services My Requests More Search"" Profile Logout Managing & Understanding My Course Course Changes 28 Nov 2024 Knowledge A course transfer allows you to change from your current degree to a different degree at Macquarie University. Student must meet the course entry requirements listed in theCourse Transfer Requirements Table. NOTE: Course transfers are not automatic, and not all courses are available for transfer. Here are the answers to some frequently asked questions about course transfer.  Before you transfer to a new undergraduate degree, it is important to know the implications of your course transfer. Please read through theCourse Guidance: Course Progression. You can seekCourse Guidancefor further information on how course transfer may affect your study.  There is no internal transfer process available to domestic or international postgraduate students. If you wish to transfer to a different postgraduate course, you must submit anew admissionsapplicationfor your desired course.  If you have an Academic Standing of ‘Monitored Enrolment’ or ‘Probation’, you must seekCourse Guidancebefore submitting a course transfer request.  When transferring to most double degrees, you must complete the core components of both single degrees that you wish to transfer to. This means that you may not have a flexible zone in your new degree program When transferring to a double degree, you will be admitted to the latest curriculum for both degrees. For example, if a Bachelor of Archeology students from 2021 adds a Bachelor of Information Technology, they would have both degrees updated to the 2025 curriculum. If you have further questions about your course transfer's impact, please refer toCourse Guidance.  If you wish to transfer to any of the teacher education degrees, you must be aware of the following information. As a part of the New South Wales Education Standards Authority (NESA) accreditation requirements, all students completing an initial teaching degree need to demonstrate suitability for teaching. If you wish to transfer to a teaching degree, you will be required to complete a short survey about your learning approaches and dispositions as a future teacher. This survey will be emailed to you as part of the Course Transfer process and is a requirement for your future accreditation as a teacher. If you do not complete this survey, your Course Transfer cannot be processed.  Important:The data collected from this survey also helps to provide relevant and effective learning experiences for Teacher Education students enrolled in Macquarie University’s courses. It is reported annually to NESA as part of our accreditation requirements. You may also be required to meet with an academic from the School of Education regarding your responses.  If you want to make changes to your course, it is important to understand how your fees will be impacted. Domestic students Legislation changes have impacted the student contribution rates from 2021. Even if you commenced your studies with us prior to 2021, you may be charged new student contribution amounts for your new course. Different types of course transfer will have different contribution rate impacts. The following categories of students will be classified asnew studentsfor the new course and will be charged new student contribution amounts. Students add a course to create a double degree, Students add a course to create a double degree, Students drop a course from a double degree, or Students drop a course from a double degree, or Students change to a different course Students change to a different course To find out more information on how your course transfer may affect your fees and Student learning entitlement (SLE), visitCommonwealth Supported Places (CSP) andLegislation changes impacting SLE. Things to note: If your course transfer application is approved, you will be required to submit a new eCAF form via eStudent for your new course.  Special category visa New Zealand citizens If you have been previously approved for HELP eligibility as a Special Category Visa New Zealand citizen and your course transfer has been approved and finalised. You must inform us via theService Connect Portalso we can re-apply your eligibility to defer your fees to a HELP loan to your new course.  International Students If you’re an international student, your fees may change depending on the degree you choose to transfer to. Please checkInternational feesfor further information.  Applications for undergraduate course transfer generally take 20 business days to be processed.  While your course transfer application is under review, you may notice some changes to your eStudent account. To process your course transfer, your access to a few functions in eStudent will be limited. Once finalised, your access will be restored.  If your course transfer application is approved, you will receive an email confirming that your eStudent access has been restored. The course transfer process includes the following stages: Your current course will be discontinued, and any future enrolments from your previous course will be withdrawn Your current course will be discontinued, and any future enrolments from your previous course will be withdrawn You will be admitted into the latest curriculum, and you will have a new weighted Average Mark (WAM) You will be admitted into the latest curriculum, and you will have a new weighted Average Mark (WAM) Your Academic Standing will roll over to your new course Your Academic Standing will roll over to your new course Passed units from your old degree may be transferred to your new degree, while failed or withdrawn units will remain on your transcript under your old course. Passed units from your old degree may be transferred to your new degree, while failed or withdrawn units will remain on your transcript under your old course. You must enrol in units and register for your classes in your new course You must enrol in units and register for your classes in your new course Recognition of Prior Learning (RPL) from your non-Macquarie studies (including SIBT) will not be re-applied to your new course. You will need to re-apply for Recognition of Prior Learning to have this credit reassessed for your new course. Recognition of Prior Learning (RPL) from your non-Macquarie studies (including SIBT) will not be re-applied to your new course. You will need to re-apply for Recognition of Prior Learning to have this credit reassessed for your new course.  If you are a domestic student and you do not intend to study in your first session, you can apply for aLeave of Absencein your new course. If you are an international student and you do not intend to study in your first session, you can apply for aSuspension of Studiesin your new course.  If your course transfer application is not approved, you will be notified by email of the specificeligibility or requirement criteriathat you have not met. Home Articles Services My Requests More Search"" Profile Logout Managing & Understanding My Course 26 Dec 2024 Knowledge This article provides details about Recognition of Prior Learning and when to apply for it. What is Recognition of Prior Learning? Recognition of Prior Learning is for students wanting to have their prior study, work and other learning experiences recognised towards their Macquarie University course. Macquarie University recognises two main forms of prior learning for potential credit: Formal learningFormal learning is part of a structured program that leads to the full or partial achievement of an officially accredited qualification undertaken at a tertiary institution (eg university, TAFE or private college) Formal learningFormal learning is part of a structured program that leads to the full or partial achievement of an officially accredited qualification undertaken at a tertiary institution (eg university, TAFE or private college) Informal or non-formal leaningInformal learningis gained through work, social and family experiences. It is not organised or externally structured in terms of objectives, time or learning support.Non-formal learningtakes place through a structured program of learning but does not lead to an officially accredited qualification. Informal or non-formal leaningInformal learningis gained through work, social and family experiences. It is not organised or externally structured in terms of objectives, time or learning support.Non-formal learningtakes place through a structured program of learning but does not lead to an officially accredited qualification. Please find answers to frequently asked questions about Recognition of Prior Learning (RPL) below.  There are two types of credit you can receive: Specified credit - where your prior learning meets the learning outcomesfor a specific Macquarie University unit or units. Specified credit - where your prior learning meets the learning outcomesfor a specific Macquarie University unit or units. Unspecified credit - credit that is granted towardsyour flexible zone at an appropriate level of learning. Unspecified credit - credit that is granted towardsyour flexible zone at an appropriate level of learning.  Undergraduate studies can be assessed for Recognition of Prior Learning credit towards 6000-level units in postgraduate programs.  The maximum amount of Recognition of Prior Learning that can be granted for particular qualifications is determined in accordance with theSchedule of Equivalenciesand theSchedule of Minimum Requirementsat Macquarie University.  Depending on the type of prior learning and type of credit you wish to receive, you may need to provide one or more of the following: an official academic transcript from your prior institution unit guides evidence of prior work experience If you are applying forRecognition of Prior Learning for a PACEunit, you will need to provide the following: If you would like to apply based on formal studies, you must provide:an official academic transcriptofficial and detailed unit outline of prior unitcompletedPACE Recognition of Prior Learning formfor each of theunits that you are seeking as specified creditYour current résuméLetter/s of reference written on official letterhead from current or past employers (including director supervisors), verifying your knowledge, skills, duration of service and experiencePosition description/s an official academic transcript official and detailed unit outline of prior unit completedPACE Recognition of Prior Learning formfor each of theunits that you are seeking as specified credit Your current résumé Letter/s of reference written on official letterhead from current or past employers (including director supervisors), verifying your knowledge, skills, duration of service and experience Position description/s  If you would like to apply based on non-formal/informal experience such as work experience, you must provide:a current résuméletter/s of reference written on official letterhead from current or past employers (including direct supervisors) verifying your knowledge, skills, duration of service and experienceposition description/s, anda completedPACE Recognition of Prior Learning formfor each of the units that you are seeking as specified credit a current résumé letter/s of reference written on official letterhead from current or past employers (including direct supervisors) verifying your knowledge, skills, duration of service and experience position description/s, and a completedPACE Recognition of Prior Learning formfor each of the units that you are seeking as specified credit You can read more about the types ofdocumentationyou will need for your application.  The deadline for submitting your application for Recognition of Prior Learning is two weeks before the session starts. This applies to all sessions. You can still apply after this date; however, we cannot guarantee that you will receive an outcome by the time enrolment closes for that session. CheckHow to Applyfor more information on application deadlines and other useful tips.  Requests to rescind credit must be academically justified and form part of an academic success intervention strategy. To requesttorescind credit, please submit an enquiry via theService Connect Portalwith the subject line: Rescind Credit. Important:requests must be received before the published RPL application deadlines as this will affect your enrolment for the upcoming Session. Home Articles Services My Requests More Search"" Profile Logout Managing & Understanding My Course Course Changes 14 Oct 2024 Knowledge Thechange of major, minor, or specialisation formallows you to request a change to one or more of the following: Majors (qualifying majors and/or flexible zone majors) Minors Specialisations (undergraduate and postgraduate degrees) Your course requirements can be found in the Course Handbook, which will provide you with details on your admitted course, including whether there are any major, minor, specialisation, and/or concentration requirements. Information about course requirements and the Curriculum Architecture can also be found in theCurriculum Architecture Policy.  A minor is a sequence of undergraduate units drawn from a major or specialisation but with a smaller volume of learning requirement. A minor must be 40 credit points, of which 20 credit points must be completed at 2000 level or above.  A major consists of 80 credit points, of which 30 credit points must be at 3000 level. The list of eligible qualifying majors for a degree are included in the course’s 'major schedule' in the Course Handbook.  The Flexible Zone major may be chosen from all available majors listed in the Handbook. The major will be added from the year that you commenced your course. If the major is not available in your course year but is available in a future year, the major will be added from the first available year after your course commencement year.  If you are admitted into a double degree, you will need to complete the core zone of each component single degree. Your major, minor, and specialisation requirements will be determined by the requirements of the individual single degrees. There are unit sharing restrictions within double degrees, which mean that students are unable to complete a specialisation or major where it is possible to choose a combination of units which share more than 50 per cent of credit points in common 1000 level and above with: a major or specialisation from the other course, or the core zone of the other course (outside any major or specialisation)  Masters degrees may require completion of a specialisation in the core zone. In postgraduate specialist courses, specialisations will constitute 50 per cent of a course’s core zone units. Where applicable, the list of eligible specialisations for a Masters degree is included in the course’s 'specialisation schedule' in theCourse Handbook.  For all change of major and minor requests relating to Open Universities Australia courses, please contactOpen Universities Australia.  You can find information about the career prospects of different majors/specialisations on the Macquarie UniversityFind a coursewebpage. Please also check your course overview (and major overviews) in theCourse Handbook. For career resources, you can also contact theCareers and Student Employmentteam. TheCourse Guidance formhas more helpful information about how changing your major/specialisation can affect your studies. Home Articles Services My Requests More Search"" Profile Logout Managing & Understanding My Course Course Progression 26 Dec 2024 Knowledge Your Academic Standing indicates your current progress towards completing your Course. It is calculated after session results release. Session 3 units are not included in your Academic Standing calculation. Your academic standing is based on: the proportion of credit points that you passed in the current study period, together with your academic standing at the end of the previous study period. You can view your academic standing on your unofficial academic transcript at any time.Go to eStudent>My Study>Self Service Reports>unofficial transcript. You can also see your academic standing on your Result Notification, which will be emailed to you after results release. It is important for you to understand what your current academic standing is as it may affect future enrolment.  Further information Please see theAcademic Standing FAQs. If you are on a status of Academic Pause or Exclusion, you will receive an Academic Standing Notification letter to your student email address. To find out more, check outAcademic StandingandAcademic Progression. Home Articles Services My Requests More Search"" Profile Logout Managing & Understanding My Course Course Progression 14 Oct 2024 Knowledge Withdrawal Without Penalty will only be available for students who have experienced serious and unavoidable disruption to their studies after census date. Information about how to self-withdraw from units and the implications of withdrawing can be found on theWithdrawing from Units (domestic students)orWithdrawing from Unit (international students)articles. If you have been approved for Withdrawal Without Penalty for your units for this session, your study plan may now be misaligned for the following session. Please submit aCourse Guidance formfor advice. Depending on your circumstances, you may also wish to apply to: Reduce your study load Request a newConfirmation of Enrolment (eCOE)- international students only Suspension of studies  Yes, where applicable, an approved application for Withdrawal Without Penalty may result in a change to youracademic standing.  If you have passed the unit, that unit willnotbe considered for Withdrawal Without Penalty. Any unit that you have passed, even where the final mark does not reflect your usual standard, willnotbe considered for Withdrawal Without Penalty. You will not be able to retake a unit to try to improve your result.  If your studies were impacted by your circumstances more than 12 months ago, you can apply to withdraw from the affected units without penalty and receive a full refund. You must make an application for a re‑credit, remission and/or repayment either: within 12 months of your withdrawal date, or if you have not withdrawn, within 12 months of the end of the period of study in which the unit was undertaken, or was to be undertaken. For full information, please see theHigher Education Support Act 2003(HESA).  If you are an OUA student, you can apply to withdraw without penalty from your units and get your fees refunded. If your fees are paid upfront to OUA or if you are a FEE-HELP student If you submitted your applicationbefore the last withdrawal date, you also need to withdraw from your unit through the OUA Portal. OUA will assess your Withdrawal Without Financial Penalty application, so you will also need to submit a Special Circumstances request directly through OUA. You can find information about this process on theOUA Special Circumstanceswebpage. If you submitted your applicationafter the last withdrawaldate, please apply for Withdrawal Without Penalty directly with Macquarie University (so you can be assessed for Withdrawal WithoutAcademicPenalty) and forSpecial Circumstancesvia OUA (so you can be assessed for Withdrawal WithoutFinancialPenalty). If you are in a Commonwealth Supported Place (HECS-HELP) Please apply forWithdrawal Without Penaltydirectly with Macquarie University. If you submitted your application submittedbefore the last withdrawal date, please also withdraw from your unit through the OUA Portal.  If you withdraw from your unit/s after the census date, you remain liable for the Student Services and Amenities Fee. The liability is based on your enrolment load at census date. Even if a refund has been approved for withdrawal without penalty from your unit/s due to special circumstances, the Student Services and Amenities Fee cannot be refunded.  Please refer to theSuspension of Studiesrequirements and ensure your request is submitted as soon as possible if it applies to you. Your circumstances for Withdrawal Without Penalty from your units will be reviewed and assessed accordingly, aligned with the Withdrawal Procedure. For pre-existing or ongoing conditions or circumstances, there must be a clear demonstration of unforeseen deterioration, exacerbation, or worsening on or after the census date of the study period, to such an extent that it prevented successful completion of the unit. This will need to be supported by a medical certificate orProfessional Authority Form (PAF). Please see our article onSpecial Considerationfor further information. Home Articles Services My Requests More Search"" Profile Logout Managing & Understanding My Course 5 Dec 2024 Knowledge If you are an incoming exchange or study abroad student, please visitOverseas Student Health Cover (OSHC).  As an international student, you must have a valid OSHC as a condition of your student visa. Please visitOverseas Student Health Coverfor further information.  The Australian Federal Government Health Department has created aFact SheetandExplanatory Guidelines for Consumerswith useful information on the OSHC mandatory requirement for international students.  You may choose to go with Macquarie University’s OSHC provider,Medibank. Information on how to pay for your OSHC will be provided along with a Letter of Offer. Once you accept your offer to come to Macquarie University on an Exchange or Study Abroad program, you will receive a Confirmation of Enrolment (CoE). Your OSHC information is provided in your CoE. Your OSHC policy number is the same as your Macquarie University student ID.  For any concerns regarding how OSHC works, please contact theDepartment of Home Affairs (DHA).  Quick Tip:You can accessIncoming Exchange and Study Abroad Student FAQswhereyou will find answers to the most frequently asked questions before, during, and after coming to Macquarie University on one of these programs.
